title: Ohio State Spending Investigation
thesis: Ohio's government spending system is designed to transfer public money to private interests through a series of mechanisms that make the transfers appear legitimate while removing any accountability.
subtitle: This is not incompetence. This is not inefficiency. This is design.
conclusion: The spending is not designed to serve the public. It's designed to serve the people who control it.
elevatorPitch: Ohio's government spending system is designed to transfer public money to private interests. The proof: spending grows 40x faster than population, contractors who fail get more money, and oversight committees are dissolved at 2 AM when they start investigating. This isn't incompetence - Medicaid directors own stock in the companies they give contracts to, prison directors come from the companies they sell prisons to, and the one politician who got caught took $60 million in bribes. The system isn't broken. It's working exactly as designed - just not for taxpayers.

scandals.name: Deloitte Unemployment Fraud
scandals.summary: Deloitte built Ohio's unemployment system (uFACTS) that enabled $3.8 billion in fraud during COVID
details: Contract value: $120.3 million through 9 amendments
Contract language prioritized 'speed over non-critical functionality'
Fraud rate jumped from 3.5% to 26% of all payments
Data breach exposed 120,000+ Ohioans' private information
State Auditor: 'We're not real impressed with the job Deloitte did, candidly'
Despite failures, Deloitte still receives Ohio contracts
scandals.outcome: No prosecution. Deloitte got $207M more in contracts.
scandals.quote: We have serious concerns about Deloitte's lack of security protocols.

scandals.name: JMOC Dissolution at 2 AM
scandals.summary: The Joint Medicaid Oversight Committee was dissolved at 2 AM while investigating Gainwell Technologies
details: Committee was actively investigating Medicaid contractor Gainwell
Language dissolving JMOC inserted into budget bill at 2 AM
Committee chair wasn't informed before the vote
Top recipients of OHCA PAC (Medicaid lobby): Huffman ($45K), McColley ($24K)
Those same two politicians led the dissolution
scandals.outcome: $54 billion in MCO contracts now have no legislative oversight.

scandals.name: Aramark Prison Food Crisis
scandals.summary: Aramark's prison food service had maggots in food, shortages, and safety violations - contract renewed anyway
details: Maggots found in prison food multiple times
Food shortages led to prisoner unrest
State fined Aramark $235,000 for violations
Despite documented failures, contract was renewed
Current contract value: $130M annually
scandals.outcome: Contract renewed. Now receiving $242M from state.

scandals.name: CoreCivic Violence Crisis
scandals.summary: Violence at CoreCivic's Lake Erie prison increased 180-300% after privatization
details: Lake Erie Correctional Institution sold to CoreCivic in 2011
Gary Mohr, former CCA (CoreCivic) executive, approved the sale as Prison Director
Violence increased 180-300% compared to state-run facilities
Staffing levels consistently below requirements
No meaningful consequences for performance failures

scandals.name: Corcoran Stock Conflict
scandals.summary: Medicaid Director Maureen Corcoran owned stock in companies she awarded $22 billion to
details: Owned stock in UnitedHealth, CVS Health, Humana
Directed $22 billion to Medicaid MCOs she had financial interest in
Refused to disclose exact amounts (reported only '≥$1,000')
Ohio's defense: 'Only parent companies, not subsidiaries'
Came from Vorys Health Care Advisors, returned to Vorys after leaving government

scandals.name: FirstEnergy Bribery (The Proven Case)
scandals.summary: The largest bribery scandal in Ohio history proves the system can work this way
details: $60 million to Larry Householder's dark money group
$4.3 million directly to PUCO Chair Sam Randazzo
Governor DeWine appointed Randazzo to regulate the company that bribed him
DeWine signed the bribery-purchased bill (HB6)
Householder sentenced to 20 years in federal prison
scandals.outcome: Householder in prison. DeWine will testify at civil trial.
